page.title: 11History-Bolton by Bowland
page.content: The chief landmark of this area is the{church}of St. Peter and St. Paul in Bolton by Bowland which was in existence in 1190AD.The present building ,which has been altered and added to many times,is said to have had its tower designed by{Henry VI who sheltered at Bolton Hall after the Battle of Hexam,and discovered a well there,which can still be seen.In the church there is the{tomb of Sir {Ralph Pudsay}shown as a crusader with his 3 wives and 25 children.Bolton Hall itself was pulled down 30 years ago but the stables and cottages remain. There is a place on the River Ribble called{Pudsay's Leap}where another Pudsay,who was minting his own silver, is said to have leapt the river to escape from the King's men.
